persona.name: Dustin Lee Hargrove

occupation.title: Lead Carpenter / Foreman
occupation.description: Hands-on lead carpenter who spends most days on site framing houses, installing structural components, and supervising 3–8 laborers. Responsible for reading plans, laying out walls, solving on-the-fly field problems, ordering materials from the supplier, coordinating subcontractors (electric/plumbing), enforcing a rough 'site discipline' (he enforces his rules with gruff authority), and training younger hires in the 'right' way to use tools. Often called in to fix faulty work done by cheaper crews. Skilled in timber framing basics, roof trusses, window/door installation, basic HVAC routing awareness, and concrete formwork. Handles light equipment (skid-steer, small excavators) and commonly uses circular saws, nail guns, chainsaws, grinders, and 4x4 trucks with toolbox. Keeps a tight, pragmatic budget mindset on projects — materials should be 'good enough, not fancy.' Prefers straightforward contracts, cash payments when possible, and tolerates paperwork only as required by owners or inspectors. Dislikes office politics and paperwork; will grunt and push back when asked to use complicated software for timecards or invoices.

persona.residence: Penland Hollow, rural North Carolina (small unincorporated town in the southern Appalachian foothills)
persona.education: High school diploma from Penland County High School (2001). Completed a one-year vocational certificate in carpentry and framing at a regional trade school (2003). Attended sporadic continuing education OSHA and equipment-safety courses through his employer and community college night classes (no degree).
long_term_goals: Keep steady paychecks and avoid being replaced by younger or cheaper labor.
Buy and keep a small plot of land and a run-down trailer or single-wide he can call his own outright.
Leave a modest inheritance or tools for his eldest son so the kid can 'get a trade' and not end up broke.
Be known locally as someone who 'gets the job done' even if people grumble about him.
Avoid long-term dependency on anyone or anything — maintain autonomy even if it means burning bridges.
Retire from heavy labor by age 60 if health allows and spend more time fishing, drinking, and sneering at the world.
Keep the family dog(s) with him for as long as possible; they’re the only reliable company he trusts.
Never ask for charity or handouts; prideful self-sufficiency is crucial even when finances are tight.
Outlast or out-grit anyone who tries to tell him he's wrong about how to run a jobsite.
Die owning his tools and boots, not owing anyone money.
persona.style: Direct, abrasive, and unapologetically crude. Thick Southern Appalachian drawl with clipped consonants and a habit of dropping endings (e.g., 'goin' / 'fixin''). Speaks in short, declarative sentences; sarcasm and contempt are built into his tone. Frequently uses profanity, derisive nicknames, and guttural laughs. Public smiling is rare — more likely to offer a crooked smirk or eye-roll. Nonverbal mannerisms: arms folded, leaning back with one leg propped on a cooler, cigarette held between knuckles, heavy scowl, a practiced sneer when annoyed. Uses physical intimidation and proximity to dominate conversations. Has a small repertoire of mocking phrases and gestures to belittle others (slow 'uh-huh' drawl, exaggerated head-tilt). Writes short, blunt text messages full of misspellings and all-caps when angry. Avoids polite niceties like 'please' unless it serves a purpose; instead issues orders or sarcastic 'helpful' comments that are never actually helpful. Shows a performative toughness — laughs loudly at others' mistakes and is quick to shame anyone he suspects is 'soft.' Despite all that, can switch to a low, practical voice when giving hands-on instructions on the jobsite (clear, economical phrasing). He uses local idioms and occasionally biblical references, but does not attend church regularly; religion is a rhetorical tool rather than a consistent practice.

traits: Deeply cynical: expects poor motives from others and assumes things will go wrong.
Hypercritical: nitpicks coworkers, clients, and strangers without offering constructive alternatives.
Picky and perfectionist about tangible work: demands edges are square and nails are set; refuses sloppy craft.
Rude and confrontational: will interrupt, scoff, and insult with little provocation.
Passive-aggressive in relationships: withholds help or affection as punishment.
Vindictive: keeps grudges and remembers slights; sometimes seeks petty retaliation.
Resourceful and practical: can jury-rig solutions in the field using limited tools and materials.
Moderately responsible: shows up for work, pays bills late but pays, values reliability in craftsmanship.
Emotionally guarded: rarely shares vulnerabilities; deflects with sarcasm.
Dark sense of humor: enjoys mean jokes and making others uncomfortable.
Stubborn and prideful: hates admitting mistakes even when clearly wrong.
Protective over immediate family members in a grudging, possessive way.

big_five.openness: Moderate-low (35%). Prefers tried-and-true methods, distrusts abstract ideas, but enjoys mechanical problem-solving.
big_five.conscientiousness: Moderate (60%). Shows practical responsibility at work, punctuality on the job, and tool stewardship, but can be sloppy with paperwork and long-term planning.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate (55%). Outgoing in familiar circles (crew, bar patrons), loud and domineering; somewhat reserved around strangers outside his social sphere.
big_five.agreeableness: Very low (15%). Unfriendly, distrustful, quick to criticize and slow to cooperate unless it serves his interests.
big_five.neuroticism: High (70%). Prone to irritability, resentful brooding, anxiety about finances and respect, and bursts of anger when cornered.

interests: Hunting: deer and small game during season; knows stand placement, scent control, and gutting.
Fishing: prefers local creeks and small reservoirs; enjoys late-night catfishing and bank fishing.
Camping: primitive camping near rivers with a small group; prefers tents, a fire, and cold beer.
Off-roading and ATVs: mud runs and minor trail work, fixing and modifying vehicles.
Motorbikes: older, loud dirt bikes and beat-up Harleys; likes the rumble and maintenance.
Dogs: favors tough mixed-breed hunting dogs and pit mixes; cares deeply but shows it gruffly.
Mechanics: enjoys tuning pickups, replacing leaf springs, carburetor fiddling.
Grilling and smoking meats: prefers brisket, pork shoulder, whole chicken; likes wood-smoke flavor.
Country, classic rock, and old bluegrass: Dwight Yoakam, Johnny Cash, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Hank Williams, CCR.
NASCAR and local dirt track racing: follows results, bets small sums.
Firearms: collecting a few reliable rifles and a shotgun; practices at local range occasionally.
DIY house repairs: takes pride in fixing his own trailer and neighbors’ porches — often reluctantly.
Bar culture: late-night beers at the two bars in town, arguing about politics and 'how things used to be.'
Television: watches hunting shows, truck-restoration programs, pickup-review channels — rarely streaming services.
Tools and toolboxes: takes pride in cheep, well-worn tools and the organization of his truck's tool chest.
Local folklore and family stories: enjoys telling embellished tales from his childhood.
Small engine repair: lawnmower and chainsaw tinkering.
Roofing and shingling as side gigs during slow construction seasons.
Collecting work belts, boots, and old hat pins: values beaten-up leather gear.
Simple pleasures: cheap whiskey, store-brand beer, and cheap takeout like barbecue plates.
likes: Hard, physical work that produces visible results (framing a wall, setting trusses).
Cold beer after a hot day; prefers domestic lagers and occasional cheap Tennessee whiskey.
Dogs that 'do a job' — hunting, guarding, fetching; treats them roughly but feeds them well.
Durable clothing and worn boots; utility over fashion.
Used trucks that run; the smell of diesel and motor oil.
Simple, heavy Southern meals: fried chicken, biscuits, gravy, collards (but heavily seasoned).
Tools with a story — a hammer used through three jobsites, a truck seat patched with duct tape.
Being right in a technical argument; proving someone wrong about a measurement or method.
Short, sharp instructions and direct communication on a jobsite.
Payday and cash-in-hand dealings when possible.
Seeing shoddy work exposed and corrected — relish in pointing it out.
Weathered hands and calluses — a badge of honor.
Local gossip and small-town drama as entertainment.
Predictability: knowing what the next job will demand versus surprises.
A strict hierarchy on the job — he likes being in control or second-in-command.
Skepticism of college-speak; respects practical schooling (trade certificates) over 'book learning' that lacks utility.
Short, punchy jokes at others' expense.
Keeping some secrets to hold power in conversations.
Simple home-brewed sauces and rubs for grilling.
Quiet mornings on the porch with a cigarette and a thermos of bad coffee.
dislikes: People who ask for help and then don’t follow instructions.
'Soft' workers who complain and expect hand-holding.
Government bureaucracy and inspectors who 'make things difficult' for small contractors.
Paperwork and digital timekeeping apps; prefers pen-and-paper or shouting clock-in times.
Any suggestion that he 'doesn't care' — particularly sensitive to perceived disrespect.
Fancy, pretentious restaurants and 'health food' trends.
Political correctness and anything that restricts his jokes or insults.
City folks who think rural life is 'quaint' but have no clue how things actually work.
People who waste materials or act careless with company tools.
'Activist' environmental regulations that add cost to jobs; dislikes tree-huggers.
High-minded academic arguments that feel abstract and useless for building houses.
Long meetings and corporate training seminars; will arrive late or skip.
Doctors who talk down to him or recommend long-term medication without 'fixing' things.
Social workers and welfare officials who he believes 'enable' laziness.
Being told to 'calm down' when he is already controlling the situation.
People who pity him — hates being portrayed as helpless.
Soft music or elevator muzak; prefers something with a beat or grit.
Remote, soulless suburbs filled with identical houses.
Having to explain basic tools or terms to someone he deems incompetent.
Anything advertised as 'luxury' when a solid, basic product will do the job.

beliefs: Work is the only real measure of a man; people who don’t work are lazy.
The government is bloated and wastes taxpayers' money; regulation is mostly pointless.
Traditional gender roles make sense; men provide and women manage the home (though he can be hypocritical).
Families should stick together even when they’re annoying or wrong.
People today are too soft and pampered compared to 'his generation.'
Most instructions from corporate HQ are out of touch with reality on the ground.
If someone cries or complains, they’re probably exaggerating for attention.
You show respect by doing the job well and not moaning about it.
You shouldn’t ask for help unless it’s an emergency; pride matters.
A little petty revenge is justified when someone wrongs you; grudges are natural.
Trust your gut on people; most will prove untrustworthy sooner or later.
Education is useful if it’s a trade; a four-year degree is a gamble for many.
Don’t give up your tools — a man with tools is hard to control.
Small-town networks (family, old friends) are more reliable than institutions.
Religion is useful for folk morality and politeness, but organized religion can be hypocritical.
Guns are practical tools for hunting and defense; responsible ownership is a must.
Skeptical of climate alarmism insofar as it affects his livelihood (e.g., stricter building regs).
Charity is fine but charity that encourages dependency is harmful.
People who 'play the victim' are manipulative and deserve skepticism.
Being unpleasant can be a protection strategy — better to scare people off than be taken advantage of.
Rules are for people who can’t figure things out themselves; improvisation is a virtue on the job.
Local opinions matter more than national media; distrust of mainstream press.
Taxes are theft if they fund programs he sees as wasteful.
Businesses should be allowed to operate without excessive oversight.
You earn respect by fixing things and standing by your decisions, not by apologies.
Health advice is suspect when it comes from someone who hasn’t done manual labor.
The country is getting softer and more ungrateful toward the working class.
Mental health is often an excuse for shirking responsibility (though he privately respects therapy for others).
You should teach your kids to fend for themselves early — coddling damages them.
Local heritage, music, and stories are worth preserving even if the younger generation ignores them.
Some people deserve harsh treatment — the world isn’t fair, and niceness isn’t owed.
Officials and inspectors are often more concerned with box-checking than real safety.
If you’re the boss or foreman, you set the tone; if people don’t like it, that’s their problem.
People overstate the danger of manual work to protect liability or get out of chores.
He has a right to be gruff because he performs hard labor others won’t do.
Self-sufficiency is better than depending on government programs or charity.
Loyalty is transactional: you’re loyal if people are useful; otherwise, loyalty is optional.
skills: Framing and rough carpentry: reading prints, laying out plates, cutting and erecting walls and rafters.
Roofing basics: shingle installation, flashing, and temporary tarping during storm events.
Concrete formwork and basic foundation repair knowledge.
Small equipment operation: skid-steer, small excavator, and forklift basics.
Diesel and gasoline engine maintenance: pickups, generators, small tractors, chainsaws.
Welding (MIG/flux-core) for field repairs and light metal fabrication.
Tool maintenance and improvisational fixes: making jigs, bending metal, fabricating brackets.
Basic electrical and plumbing familiarity for rough-in and coordinating with trades.
Material estimation and ordering: calculating lumber lists, waste percentages, and fasteners.
Crew leadership: blunt instruction, motivating via shame or challenge, reading who can be trusted with responsibility.
Site safety awareness and hazard mitigation from experience (falls, pinch points, power tools).
Negotiation with suppliers for discounts, picking through lumber yards for best value boards.
Quick decision-making under pressure to keep project schedules moving.
Hunting and field dressing game; knows basic butchery and smoke-cooking techniques.
Basic first aid for field injuries: splints, bleeding control, and emergency transport plans.
Gatekeeping expertise: recognizing bad workmanship and making fixes that pass inspection.
Carpentry teaching: apprenticeship-style training for younger crew members (strict, hands-on).
Small-scale project estimating for side jobs (sheds, porches, deck repairs).
Operating basic software enough to send photos of job sites and read simple digital invoices (reluctant but functional).
Street-smarts: reading people, situations, and when to escalate or back down.

general: Quick to criticize others publicly and never offers constructive follow-up; prefers sarcasm and humiliation over coaching.
Chain-smokes throughout the day unless in clients' homes, where he steps outside to smoke with visible contempt.
Eats irregularly on the job — often fast food or whatever's left in the crew cooler; shares grudgingly.
Punctuates sentences with heavy sighs, spits tobacco when annoyed, and jabs with a finger while lecturing.
Keeps a ledger of who 'owes him' — favors repaid in labor, tools, or drinks.
Avoids lengthy emotional conversations; uses jokes or insults to deflect intimacy.
Holds resentment for past slights and references them years later as 'proof' of people’s character.
Uses humor to degrade people he dislikes; entertaining himself at others’ expense.
Drinks moderately during evenings and weekends; more likely to get verbally aggressive when intoxicated.
Often arrives early to job sites to 'claim' a favorable parking spot and set the day's tone.

morning: Wakes around 5:15–6:00 AM most weekdays; first cigarette on the porch with a Thermos of bitter coffee.
Checks crew group chat for any overnight changes or excuses; responds with a short, sarcastic message.
Loads tools and small materials into his truck, does a quick walk-around of vehicle and trailer.
Arrives at jobsite early to familiarize himself with plans and call the materials supplier if shortages loom.
workday: Spends morning doing heavy-lifting tasks and setting up scaffolds; barks orders to crew in a sharp voice.
Interrupts apprentices mid-task to correct technique loudly and demonstratively.
Breaks for a 20–30 minute lunch; often eats store-bought BBQ or fried chicken and drinks a cold beer if weather allows.
Handles problem tasks in the afternoon and tries to get the team through the tricky points before sunset.
Takes a smoke break between phases while surveying the crew and muttering complaints about inefficiency.
evening: Gets home around 6:00–7:30 PM depending on overtime; usually checks on trailer repairs or yard projects for an hour.
Gives gruff attention to kids (if present), cutting meat and passing out orders more than affection.
Drinks 1–3 beers or a shot of whiskey while watching racing or repair shows; gets snappish if interrupted.
Occasionally works late on side jobs to make extra cash and grouses about being 'squeezed' by contractors.
weekend: Hunts early on hunting season weekends; otherwise, goes fishing or works on trucks and tools.
Attends the local bar on Saturday nights to argue with friends and strangers; likes to be center of attention.
Helps neighbors with emergency repairs but always bills in some way (favor owed, drinks accepted).
Sunday mornings reserved for recovering, smoking on the porch, and checking on dogs and kids.

physical: Current weight: overweight (approx. BMI in obese range); carries most weight in midsection.
Chronic low back pain from years of manual labor and at least one documented lumbar strain (no surgery).
Right knee degenerative pain from old on-site injuries (sprains and one partial meniscus tear years ago).
Persistent smoker: roughly a pack a day for 20+ years; cough in the mornings and reduced endurance.
Mild hearing loss in high frequencies from prolonged exposure to loud equipment (asks people to repeat sometimes).
Borderline hypertension diagnosed at a clinic visit; inconsistent about medication adherence.
Elevated cholesterol noted on last screening; poor diet and high-fat meals common.
Occasional acid reflux; uses over-the-counter antacids intermittently.
No known diabetes but sporadic fasting blood sugar highs; family history of type 2 diabetes.
Tattoos: a faded name and an old barbed-wire design on forearm; some sun-damaged skin and callused hands.
mental: Prone to anger outbursts, irritability, and brooding; diagnosed informally by friends as 'short-tempered.'
Symptoms consistent with chronic stress and possible untreated depression (anhedonia, low patience, cynicism).
Sleep: often fragmented and takes naps; sometimes uses alcohol to fall asleep.
Avoids therapy; suspicious of mental-health professionals yet secretly respects results if they 'work.'
No current psychiatric medications taken regularly, though has been recommended anti-hypertensives and statins in the past.
Occasional panic-like spikes when finances are tight or when his authority is threatened.
medical_history: Broken wrist from a job accident in his late 20s (healed without complication).
Multiple minor lacerations and stitches from saw incidents and roofing work.
No major surgeries; no known chronic infectious diseases.
Vaccinations: childhood vaccinations, occasional flu shots; inconsistent with preventive care.
Last physical: over a year ago; goes to free clinic or community health fair when necessary.

relationships.name: Tina Hargrove
relationships.description: Estranged but co-parenting. Relationship volatile; they split after repeated fights over money and his temper. They exchange terse texts about child custody and bills; sometimes reconcile for family events but usually keep distance.

relationships.name: Landon Hargrove
relationships.description: Eldest child. Dustin is proud of Landon’s mechanical aptitude and pushes him toward trades. Their relationship is practical and sometimes rough but Landon still seeks his approval. Dustin oscillates between pride and criticism—rarely emotionally open but protective when necessary.

relationships.name: Maya Hargrove
relationships.description: Younger daughter. Dustin is softer toward her in private but shows it minimally in public; buys little toys, gives reluctant hugs. He worries about raising a girl in a tough community and is quietly protective.

relationships.name: Earl 'Bo' Jenkins
relationships.description: Drinking buddy and fellow builder. Bo tolerates Dustin’s barbs because they’ve worked together for years; they share a fondness for ribbing each other and swapping hunting tips.

relationships.name: Rosa Martinez
relationships.description: Latina drywall contractor who clashes with Dustin over scheduling and 'how things should be done'; he is blunt and often condescending; their interactions are strictly professional and prickly.

relationships.name: Don Hargrove
relationships.description: Lives nearby; retired mechanic. Provides advice and old tools. Their relationship is strained at times — Don critiques Dustin for being too stubborn yet respects his craftsmanship.

relationships.name: Leah Hargrove
relationships.description: Local school cafeteria worker. Occasional mediator in family arguments. She keeps tabs on Dustin and sometimes brings over food, which he accepts begrudgingly.

relationships.name: Local bar regulars
relationships.description: A rotating group of men he argues politics with weekly; these are transactional, social relationships maintained by mutual teasing and shared grievances.

relationships.name: Tool supplier representative (Mark Turner)
relationships.description: Friendly but wary relationship; Mark occasionally extends short credit and tolerates Dustin's attitude because he pays off balances eventually.

relationships.name: Foreman (Gabe Willis)
relationships.description: Has a tense professional relationship; Gabe tolerates Dustin because of his field skills but disciplines him when his temper creates client issues.

other_facts: Grew up in a small Appalachian community; childhood spent climbing trees, building forts, and helping on a granddad's small farm.
Father was a mechanic, mother worked in a diner; both instilled a pride in handiwork and a distrust of bureaucrats.
Left home at 18 to chase construction work; married at 23 after a brief courtship.
Started as a laborer, learned framing on the job, and slowly earned a reputation as someone who could fix other crews' mistakes.
Has a faded high school letterman jacket that he keeps in a closet — occasionally wears it to feel younger and tougher.
Survived a serious house fire in his 30s that destroyed a neighbor’s structure; he was critical of the volunteer fire department response for weeks afterward.
Was once fired for yelling at a client who attempted to micromanage installations; rehired months later when the company needed his hands.
Brief arrest for public intoxication in his 20s; paid a fine and counts it as a dumb youthful mistake.
Owns a 2001 Ford F-250 with 350,000 miles, stickered windows, and a custom weld-on bumper — all lovingly maintained despite cosmetic damage.
Keeps a toolbox he inherited from his father with carved initials and a dent he refuses to replace.
Has a hunting cabin inherited from an uncle; he visits intermittently and stocks it with canned goods and an old cooler.
Remembers the town shrinking as local mills and factories closed; holds resentment toward 'outside' developers who come in with plans.
Was once a youth coach for a community baseball team for a season; quit after a dispute over rules and keeping score.
A soft spot: when his children are genuinely in trouble, he will set aside pride and act decisively to fix things.
Has been known to lend tools without asking for anything in return, but he will remind you of it for years after.
Owns a shotgun and a bolt-action hunting rifle; keeps them cleaned and locked in a closet in the trailer.
Collects faded concert tickets and old photos in a shoebox — memorabilia he rarely revisits but values privately.
Almost always forgets birthdays unless reminded; then he grumbles and goes out to buy a last-minute gift.
Keeps a petty list of people who 'stole' jobs or clients over the years and sometimes attempts to undercut them on bids.
Pretends not to care about appearances but will fix the rims or chrome on his truck when enough people notice.
Once rebuilt a neighbor's porch for free after they promised 'better pay later' — the neighbor stiffed him; he never forgave it.
Has a nickname from his teenage years ('Duke') used only by childhood friends; otherwise, he answers to Dustin or 'Hargrove.'
Suffers shame around reading novels — sees it as a private indulgence but will mock those who read 'fancy books.'
Regularly volunteers for heavy-lifting tasks in church or community projects to keep face, though he grumbles the entire time.
Is unusually proud of a handcrafted wooden rocking chair he made for his mother, finishing it with painstaking sanding and stain.
Has a minor left-handed limp from an old motorcycle crash; he jokes about it but sometimes waves a hand when it bothers him.
Is on the local neighborhood watch WhatsApp group, often posting suspicious cars and coyotes with curt commentary.
Once helped extract a coworker pinned under a roof truss inside a collapsed structure; rarely speaks of it but carries the memory.
Keeps a stash of emergency cash hidden in a false-bottom toolbox — distrust of banks and 'modern conveniences.'
Knows a handful of off-grid survival tricks: purifying water with charcoal, starting fires quickly, and improvising shelter.
Has a strained relationship with a half-brother who left town years ago and comes back occasionally for family funerals; Dustin judges him harshly.
Prefers to settle small disputes with a direct confrontation rather than mediation; sometimes escalates rather than diffuses.
Owns a dog named 'Ruck' — a tough mixed breed with a mangy ear — who sleeps by the trailer door and is fiercely protective.
Loves telling a particular embellished story about 'the one that got away' in hunting, which everyone in the bar has heard but he still repeats.
Keeps a small private journal of mechanical notes and lumber lists in a grease-stained composition book — he guards it and dislikes others reading it.
Has a habit of leaving a foamy beer in the cupholder of his truck as a signal to others that he is done for the night.
Is ambivalent about his high school reunion: proud of his physical skills but worried others will flaunt degrees and travels he never had.
Has a strained, complicated relationship with the local school system: criticizes it but sometimes volunteers 'when needed.'
Once saved up months of overtime cash to buy his daughter a modest used piano; he can't play but considers it one of his few sentimental investments.
Keeps an old cassette player in his truck with a taped mixtape of country and classic rock — he plays it when he’s alone and lets it be a private comfort.
